field_edited_text.value:
SECTION C: 41ST STREET TO CYLBURN PARK

18. New Apartments and Houses: Open land at the crest of the
Valley wall will serve high-density residential needs, both
apartments and homes.

19. Meadow Park: To the expressway traveller, the wide Wood-
berry Meadow under the 41st Street viaduct will be in pleas-
ant contrast to the narrower confines and steep-sloped views
elsewhere in the Valley. Because the expressway is elevated
at this point, people on the Valley floor can walk under it
easily to the quarry area or to the south and Druid Hill Park.

20. Residential Development: The present light manufacturing
use on this hillside area is almost surrounded by school, play-
ground, and park. The area has greater, higher, and better
use in intensive residential development. {

21. Bend Hill Recreation Area: The Arundel Quarry is not a
very pretty sight today. However, through the eyes .of a
landscape architect can be seen wonderful transformations:
a boating and fishing pond on the lower level ; trees springing
from the now denuded slopes; an observation tower rising
against the 100-foot precipice to thrilling heights overlooking
the Valley and the City; and a restaurant, incorporated in the
design of the tower, to be reached from a parking area on
the upper level just off the Scenic Road. Ice skating and a
sled and ski slope would make the area a year-round enter-
prise. Many of these facilities could be leased out to private
operators thereby absorbing some of the development costs.

22. Camping: The flat hilltop just north of the quarry is an
unusually isolated spot due to its height and steep slopes on
three sides. It is an ideal site for camping. Scouts might find
a good base here from which to hike to Lake Roland and
beyond.

23. Street Improvement: The City has proposed that Shirley
Avenue be extended to Cold Spring Lane. This would become
a natural boundary of the Valley development. The Scenic
Road would connect with it, and park land would reach out
to Greenspring Avenue for pedestrian access. Y

24. Junior High School: The City is now acquiring land for this
school. Both as protection for the school site and as an entry
to the Valley, a minimum of 80’ on each side of Cold Spring
Lane should be acquired and landscaped.

25. Potential Residential Area: This open hilly tract of some
eight acres will be highly desirable residential land overlook-
ing the Valley. Near three public schools, adjacent to an ex-
pressway interchange, and close to the rapid transit line, its
logical use will be for good residences.



Bend H:ll 'recrea,tzon area

26. High Schools: This 69-acre area has been approved for the
use of two new high schools. Again, a minimum width of 80’
should be landscaped on each side of the new Cold Spring
Lane, from Falls Road into the Valley, to provide a sense of
entry as well as to buffer the schools from the highway. The
preservation of the remainder of the high hill just north of
Cold Spring Lane will provide a breath-taking lookout point
for the public. Retaining the hillside will, at the same time,
absorb expressway noise before it reaches classrooms.

27. Camp Small*‘— An Historic Site: The meadow was the site of
a Union Army Camp permanently established early in the
Civil War to protect the railroad bridge over the Jones Falls;
the bridge had been blown up during the Riots of Baltimore.
The area might appeal to the Boy Scouts for the erection of a
permanent camp site. Although it, and a few other areas,
appear to have potential for industrial use, they are even more
important as part of the visual continuity of the Valley Park.

28. Residential Development: A lovely open hillside tract of
some 37 acres, surrounded by public and semi-public uses, this
area is ideal for residential development.
